translated: Elder’s Birth Stories🔽The Chapter with Upāli
The Elder Sanniṭṭhāpaka
Having made a hut in the wilderness,
I lived in the mountains;
Content with gain and no gain,
with fame and no fame.
Padumuttara, the knower of the world,
the receiver of offerings,
With a hundred thousand powerful ones,
came into my presence.

analyzed: upāgatam mahā nāga  jalajuttama nāmaka  tiṇa santharam paññāpetvā
translated: I spread out a grass mat🔽for the great nāga, the supreme one of men,
and gave it to the Teacher.
With a confident mind, joyful,
I gave him a mango and water;
I gave it to the upright one,
with a clear mind.
For a hundred thousand eons,
the gift I gave then,
I do not know of any bad destination,
this is the fruit of the mango.
In a single eon,
I was a leader of men,
endowed with the seven treasures,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
The four analytical knowledges,
I have done the Buddha’s bidding.”

original: Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā sanniṭṭhāpako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: ittham sudam āyasmā sanniṭṭhāpakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: Thus did the Venerable Elder Sanniṭṭhāpaka recite these verses.
The Story of the Elder Sanniṭṭhāpaka is the fourth.
